facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 29 of 1950 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION. Civil Appeal No. 29 of 1950.

facts.text: Appeal against Judgment and Decree dated 10th October 1945 of High Court of Patna by Manohar Lal and Das JJ. in Appeal No. 64 of 1942.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal against the Judgment and Decree dated the 10th October, 1945, of the High Court of Judicature at Patna  Manohar Lal and Das JJ.  in Appeal No. 64 of 1942

facts.text: Arising out of decree dated 28th February 1942 of Subordinate Judge at Monghyr in Suit No. 10 of 1941.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of decree dated the 28th February, 1942, of the Subordi- nate Judge at Monghyr in Suit No. 10 of 1941.

facts.text: Judgment of Supreme Court delivered on May 2, 1951 by FAZAL ALI J.

anchor.surface_text: 1951. May 2. The judgment of the Court was delivered by FAZAL ALI J.

facts.text: Plaintiff is Maharaja of Gidhaur, proprietor of impartible estate Gidhaur raj in Monghyr district.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff, the Maharaja of Gidhaur, who has succeed- ed in both the companyrts below, is the proprietor of an impartable estate known as Gidhaur raj in the district of Monghyr.

facts.text: Ancestors of defendants 1st party held 4 annas share in ghatwali tenure Mahal Dumri Nisf Katauna T. No. 325, allotted mouza Dumri with 47 tolas by private partition.

anchor.surface_text: The ancestors of the defendants 1st party originally held a 4 annas share in a ghatwali tenure known as Mahal Dumri Nisf Katauna T. No. 325, and subsequently by private partition they were allotted mouza Dumri with its 47 tolas which are detailed in schedule I of the plaint.

facts.text: In execution of mortgage decree by Chethru Rai against ancestors of defendants 1st party, their interest purchased by Maharaja of Gidhaur in name of employee, possession taken on 19th April 1904.

anchor.surface_text: In execution of a mortgage decree obtained by one Chethru Rai against the ancestors of defendants 1st party, their interest, to which reference has been made, was purchased by the Maharaja of Gidhaur in the name of one of his employees, and the latter took delivery of possession of the property on the 19th April, 1904.

facts.text: Ancestors of defendants 1st party filed application to set aside sale on 13th August 1903, dismissed by executing court, appeals dismissed by High Court and Privy Council.

anchor.surface_text: On the 13th August, 1903, the ancestors of the defendants 1st party filed an application for setting aside the sale which was dismissed by the executing companyrt and the appeal from the order of the executing companyrt was dismissed by the High Court as well as by the Privy Council.

facts.text: Defendants second party, lessees of defendants first party, obtained mining license in 1937 from sub-divisional officer of Jamui.

anchor.surface_text: After certain disputes in the criminal companyrts, the defendants second party alleging themselves to be the lessees of the defendants first party, obtained a mining license in 1937 from the sub-divisional officer of Jamui,

facts.text: District Magistrate started proceedings under section 144 CrPC, ended in favour of defendants first and second parties against plaintiff.

anchor.surface_text: and the District Magistrate apprehending a breach of the peace, started proceedings under section 144 of the Criminal Procedure Code, which ended in favour of the defendants first and second parties and against the plaintiff.

facts.text: Defendants started working mines in tolas in schedule II, extracted considerable quantity of mica, compelling plaintiff to institute suit.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs case is that, emboldened by the order in the proceedings under section 144, the defendants started working mines in the tolas mentioned in schedule II of the plaint and extracted a companysiderable quantity of mica and hence he was companypelled to institute the present suit.

facts.text: Suit No. 10 of 1941 for declaration of subsoil rights in entire Mahal Dumri, possession of mortgage lands in schedule II, mesne profits, permanent injunction against extracting minerals.

anchor.surface_text: In this suit, after reciting the facts to which reference has been made he prayed for a declara- tion of the subsoil rights with regard to the entire Mahal Dumri and for recovery of possession of the mortgage lands situated in the tolas specified in schedule 11 of the plaint. He also prayed for mesne profits and a permanent injunction restraining the defendants first and second parties from extracting mica or other underground minerals from the lands mentioned in schedule II of the plaint.

facts.text: Plaintiff claims as 16 annas proprietor of Dumri Nisf Katauna, indefeasible right to underground minerals including mica; acquired 4 annas mokrari shares by auction purchase in 1903.

anchor.surface_text: The grounds on which these reliefs were claimed are summarized in paragraph 12 of the plaint in these words - That the plaintiff submits that he being the 16 annas proprietor of Dumri Nisf Katauna has got an indefeasible right and title to all the underground minerals including mica situate within the said talukas. The plaintiff further submits that all the titles and interest in the said 4 annas mokrari shares of the ancestors of the defendant 1st party having been acquired by plaintiffs ancestor by auction purchase in 1903,

facts.text: Defendants 1st party claim 4 annas interest in village Dumri is ghatwali tenure granted by Muhammadan rulers, affirmed by Captain Browne.

anchor.surface_text: The case of this defendant was that the four annas interest in village Dumri was a ghatwali tenure grant- ed to the ancestors of the defendants first party by Muham- madan rulers to guard the hill passes in the taluka, and the grant under which they held was affirmed subsequently by Captain Browne, a representative of the East India Company.

facts.text: Defendants claim mineral and subsoil rights vested in holder of ghatwali tenure; auction purchase invalid as Government ghatwali inalienable.

anchor.surface_text: The defendant No. 1 further companytended that the mineral and subsoil rights were vested in him as the holder of the ghatwali tenure, and that the plaintiff had numberright by his auction-purchase in 1903 inasmuch as the property in suit being Government ghatwali tenure was inali- enable and companysequently the auction-purchase was invalid.

facts.text: Defendants claim adverse possession over mines and minerals for more than 12 years prior to suit.

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, it was companytended that this defendant and his ances- tors had been exercising rights of possession over the mines and minerals for more than 12 years prior to the suit in assertion of their ghatwali right and to the knowledge of The plaintiff and his ancestors and had thus acquired an indefeasible right by adverse possession to the mines and minerals in suit,

facts.text: Subordinate Judge decreed suit: tenure zamindary ghatwali, not inalienable, plaintiff in possession since 1903 until 1938 order, entitled to mineral rights.

anchor.surface_text: The Subordinate Judge decreed the suit, holding among other things that the disputed tenure was a zamindary ghat- wali tenure that it was number inalienable, that the plaintiff had been in possession of the property since he purchased it in 1903 until the order of the District Magistrate made in 1038, that the plaintiff as the proprietor of the Mahal was entitled to the mineral and subsoil rights

facts.text: High Court affirmed Subordinate Judge, held subsoil rights with proprietor or passed in 1903 mortgage-sale; rejected adverse possession.

anchor.surface_text: The findings of the Subordinate Judge were sub- stantially upheld on appeal by the High Court, with this modification that, while agreeing with the Subordinate Judge that the subsoil rights remained with the proprietor, the High Court also held that even if the defendant No. 1 was assumed to have had the subsoil rights, those rights passed at the mortgage-sale of 1903 and therefore in any event the plaintiff was the real owner of the subsoil. On the plea of adverse possession raised in defence, the finding of the High Court was that there was numberclear evidence that any mine was worked on behalf of the lessees of defendant No. 1

facts.text: Ghatwali sanad granted in 1776 (1184 Fasli) by Captain Browne to ancestors of appellant.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the appellant relies upon exhibit C  1 , which is a ghatwali sanad granted in 1776 to the ancestors of the appellant and which runs as follows -- Know ye the Chaudhuris, kanungoes, zamindars and mutasaddis of mauza Dumri Ghat  illegible  pargana Gidhaur, Sarkar Monghyr companyprised in the province of Bihar.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds tenure is zamindary ghatwali, not Government ghatwali, alienable; plaintiff owner of subsoil rights.

anchor.surface_text: This brief review of the evidence is sufficient to show that the appellant has number been able by clear and companyclusive evidence to rebut the presumption arising from the Record of Rights and the record of the Permanent Settlement, and he has failed to establish his claim that the tenure in ques- tion is Government ghatwali.

facts.text: Supreme Court upholds concurrent findings against adverse possession plea.

anchor.surface_text: Passing number to the second point raised in this appeal, we find that there are companycurrent findings of both the companyrts below against the defendants on the plea of adverse possession.

facts.text: Tenure included in Gidhaur zamindary in Permanent Settlement and as istemrari mokrari in Record of Rights.

anchor.surface_text: In the first place, the appellants tenure was included within the Gidhaur zamindary in the Permanent Settlement, and secondly, it is shown in the Record of Rights as istemrari mokrari tenure under the zamindar of Gidhaur.
under section 144 of the Criminal Procedure Code, which ended in favour of the defendants first and second parties and against the plaintiff.

arguments.claim: Government ghatwali is tenure created by ruling power for ghatwali services to it; zamindary ghatwali created by zamindar

anchor.surface_text: A Government ghatwali is thus a tenure created by the ruling power in favour of a person who is required to render ghatwali services to it, whereas a zamindary ghatwali is a tenure created by a zamindar

arguments.claim: Government ghatwali uniformly held inalienable; zamindary ghatwali alienable with consent of zamindar

anchor.surface_text: a Government ghatwali has been uniformly held to be inalienable. On the other hand, a zamindary ghatwali may be alienated with the companysent of the zamindar

arguments.claim: Sanad exhibit C-1 is authority to collect ghatwari fees, not grant of land; to be read with Dewani Adalat proceedings showing grant by zamindar

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the appellant relies upon exhibit C  1 , which is a ghatwali sanad granted in 1776 to the ancestors of the appellant... It is number a grant of land but an authority to the persons named to companylect as formerly ghatwari of ghatwali fees or tolls

arguments.claim: Tenure included in Gidhaur zamindary in Permanent Settlement and as istemrari mokrari in Record of Rights, raising presumption of zamindary ghatwali

anchor.surface_text: In the first place, the appellants tenure was included within the Gidhaur zamindary in the Permanent Settlement, and secondly, it is shown in the Record of Rights as istemrari mokrari tenure under the zamindar of Gidhaur.

arguments.claim: Appellant failed to rebut presumption by clear conclusive evidence; tenure not Government ghatwali

anchor.surface_text: This brief review of the evidence is sufficient to show that the appellant has number been able by clear and companyclusive evidence to rebut the presumption arising from the Record of Rights and the record of the Permanent Settlement, and he has failed to establish his claim that the tenure in ques- tion is Government ghatwali.

arguments.claim: Concurrent findings of courts below against adverse possession; no reason to disturb

anchor.surface_text: Passing number to the second point raised in this appeal, we find that there are companycurrent findings of both the companyrts below against the defendants on the plea of adverse possession.

arguments.claim: Court reluctant to re-examine evidence where concurrent findings by courts below

anchor.surface_text: This companyrt is usually reluctant to reinvestigate matters which have been fully investigated by the companyrts below and on which there are companycurrent findings.

arguments.claim: Suit not barred under article 142; plaintiff not failed to prove possession within 12 years

holdings.text: The ghatwali tenure in question is not a Government ghatwali but a zamindary ghatwali; the appellant has failed to establish by clear and conclusive evidence that it is Government ghatwali, and thus the auction purchase was valid and title passed to the plaintiff.

anchor.surface_text: This brief review of the evidence is sufficient to show that the appellant has not been able by clear and conclusive evidence to rebut the presumption arising from the Record of Rights and the record of the Permanent Settlement, and he has failed to establish his claim that the tenure in question is Government ghatwali.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant failed to rebut strong presumption arising from inclusion in Permanent Settlement of Gidhaur zamindary and entry as istemrari mokrari in Record of Rights; concurrent findings of lower courts upheld after review of sanad, historical documents, and precedents distinguishing Government from zamindary ghatwali.

holdings.text: The concurrent findings of the courts below against the defendants on the plea of adverse possession must be accepted; no indefeasible right acquired by adverse possession.

anchor.surface_text: Passing now to the second point raised in this appeal, we find that there are concurrent findings of both the courts below against the defendants on the plea of adverse possession.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lower courts fully investigated evidence and gave cogent reasons; Supreme Court reluctant to re-examine facts with concurrent findings absent exceptional circumstances.

holdings.text: The plaintiff's suit is not barred by limitation under article 142 of the Limitation Act.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Plea negatived; plaintiff did not fail to prove possession within 12 years as required, based on acceptance of lower court findings on possession history.

holdings.text: The plaintiff, as proprietor of the Mahal via valid auction purchase of the alienable zamindary ghatwali tenure, is entitled to the mineral and subsoil rights.

anchor.surface_text: This brief review of the evidence is sufficient to show that the appellant has not been able by clear and conclusive evidence to rebut the presumption arising from the Record of Rights and the record of the Permanent Settlement, and he has failed to establish his claim that the tenure in question is Government ghatwali.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tenure held zamindary ghatwali (alienable), not Government ghatwali; subsoil rights vest in proprietor and passed in 1903 mortgage-sale; upholds lower court decrees granting declaration, possession, injunction, and mesne profits.

anchor.surface_text: Privy Council in Kali Prasad v. Ananda Rai 1  are pertinent -- When once it is established that the ghatwal had the power of alienation, as before stated, that power forms an integral portion of his right and interest in the ghatwali, and there is noevidence whatever to limit it to an alienation for his own life and no longer.

precedents.cited_proposition: Power of alienation of zamindary ghatwali tenure is integral and not limited to lifetime
precedents.cited_holding: When once it is established that the ghatwal had the power of alienation... no longer.

anchor.surface_text: Passing now to the second point raised in this appeal, we find that there are concurrent findings of both the courts below against the defendants on the plea of adverse possession. In arriving at this finding, the courts below have fully discussed the evidence and given cogent reasons in support of their conclusions. This Court is usually reluctant to reinvestigate matters which have been fully investigated by the courts below and on which there are concurrent findings. In the present case, the appellant has failed to show to us any exceptional circumstances to induce us to depart from the sound and well established practice, and in this view the findings of the court below must be accepted. It was however contended that in any event the plaintiffs suit is barred under article 142 of the Limitation Act inasmuch as it was incumbent on the plaintiff to prove that he had been in possession of the disputed lands, especially those mentioned in schedule II of the plaint, within 12 years of the suit, but he had failed to do so. In our opinion, this plea must be negatived.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal dismissed; concurrent findings of lower courts upheld declaring zamindary ghatwali tenure (alienable), plaintiff entitled to subsoil/mineral rights via 1903 purchase, no adverse possession, suit not barred by limitation; declaration of title, possession, mesne profits, and injunction granted to plaintiff.

In arriving at this finding, the courts below have fully discussed the evidence and given cogent reasons in support of their conclusions. This Court is usually reluctant to reinvestigate matters which have been fully investigated by the courts below and on which there are concurrent findings. In the present case, the appellant has failed to show to us any exceptional circumstances to induce us to depart from the sound and well established practice, and in this view the findings of the court below must be accepted. It was however contended that in any event the plaintiffs suit is barred under article 142 of the Limitation Act inasmuch as it was incumbent on the plaintiff to prove that he had been in possession of the disputed lands, especially those mentioned in schedule II of the plaint, within 12 years of the suit, but he had failed to do so. In our opinion, this plea must be negatived.
